# Slide 1: motivation

\begin{frame}{Why Does Evapotranspiration Matter?}

\begin{minipage}{0.4\linewidth}
\begin{itemize}
  \item \textbf{Water resource management}
    \begin{itemize}
      \item \begin{equation*}
        Q = P - ET - \Delta S
      \end{equation*}
      \item Disturbances change the balance
    \end{itemize}
  \item \textbf{Climate warming}
    \begin{itemize}
      \item Longer fire season
      \item Hotter/drier summers
      \item Earlier snowmelt
    \end{itemize}
  \item \textbf{Forest management and tree density}
\end{itemize}
\end{minipage}

# Slide 5: Methods - Feature engineering

\begin{frame}{Creating the response variable}

\begin{minipage}{0.8\linewidth}
\tiny
\begin{equation*}
rET = \left( \frac{ET_{\text{burned,prefire}} - ET_{\text{burned,postfire}} - \left( ET_{\text{control,prefire}} - ET_{\text{control,postfire}} \right) }{ET_{\text{control,prefire}}} \right) \times 100 \%
\end{equation*}
\end{minipage}

\vspace{1em}

\begin{itemize}
  \item Absolute and relative evapotranspiration
  \item Bigger rET: more change compared to control
  \item Control: same 100-m elevation bin and HUC12 watershed
\end{itemize}

\end{frame}

# Slide 9: Results - GAM initial model

\begin{frame}{GAMs - higher complexity, higher computational cost}

\begin{align*}
\text{rET} &= \beta_0 + s_1(\text{pre-fire NDVI}) + s_2(\text{dNBR}) \\
&\quad + s_3(\text{elevation}) + s_4(\text{slope}) \\
&\quad + s_5(\text{aspect}) + s_6(\text{northness})\\
&\quad + s_7(\text{latitude}) + s_8(\text{temperature}) \\
&\quad + s_9(\text{precipitation}) + \epsilon \\
&\text{adjusted } R^2 = 0.699 \\
\end{align*}

\end{frame}

# Slide 11: Results - GAM reduced model selection

\begin{frame}{GAM reduced model}

- Initial model: $R^2 = 0.737$
- Can we reduce the number of covariates while retaining descriptive power?

\begin{align*}
\text{rET} &= \beta_0 + s_1(\text{dnbr}) + te_1(\text{dNDVI}, \text{elevation}) \\
&\quad + te_2(\text{precipitation}, \text{RdNBR})  + \epsilon\\
&\text{adjusted } R^2 = 0.770 \\
\end{align*}

\end{frame}

# Slide 14: Conclusions

\begin{frame}{Conclusions: MLR vs GAMs for describing rET}

\begin{minipage}{0.4\linewidth}
\begin{itemize}
 \item Model assumptions may not fit these data
 \item Interactions are important, but unclear which ones
 \item Relationships in elevation, precipitation, temperature
 \item dNBR and rET have a strong relationship
\end{minipage}
